an9.26:3.1: 26 The Simile of the Stone Pillar
an9.26:4.1: So I have heard. At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
an9.26:4.2: There Venerable Candikāputta addressed the mendicants:
an9.26:4.3: “Reverends, Devadatta teaches the mendicants like this:
an9.26:4.4: ‘When a mendicant’s mind is solidified by heart, it’s appropriate for them to say:
an9.26:4.5: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’
an9.26:5.1: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to him:
an9.26:5.2: “Reverend Candikāputta, Devadatta does not teach the mendicants like that.
an9.26:5.6: ‘When a mendicant’s mind is well consolidated by heart, it’s appropriate for them to say:
an9.26:5.7: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’”
an9.26:7.1: And for a third time Venerable Candikāputta addressed the mendicants …
an9.26:7.5: And for a third time, Sāriputta said to him:
an9.26:7.6: “Reverend Candikāputta, Devadatta does not teach the mendicants like that.
an9.26:7.10: ‘When a mendicant’s mind is well consolidated by heart, it’s appropriate for them to say:
an9.26:7.11: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’
an9.26:8.1: And how is a mendicant’s mind well consolidated with heart?
an9.26:8.2: The mind is well consolidated with heart when they know: ‘My mind is without greed.’
an9.26:8.5: … ‘My mind is not liable to become greedy.’
an9.26:8.6: … ‘My mind is not liable to become hateful.’
an9.26:8.7: … ‘My mind is not liable to become deluded.’
an9.26:8.8: … ‘My mind is not liable to return to rebirth in the sensual realm.’
an9.26:8.9: … ‘My mind is not liable to return to rebirth in the realm of luminous form.’
an9.26:8.10: … ‘My mind is not liable to return to rebirth in the formless realm.’
an9.26:8.11: When a mendicant’s mind is rightly freed like this, even if compelling sights come into the range of vision they don’t occupy their mind.
an9.26:8.12: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, motionless, observing disappearance.
an9.26:9.1: Suppose there was a stone pillar, sixteen feet long.
an9.26:9.2: Eight feet were buried underground, and eight above ground.
an9.26:9.3: And violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south.
an9.26:9.6: They couldn’t make it tremor and tremble and quake.
an9.26:9.8: It’s because that boundary pillar is firmly embedded, with deep foundations.
an9.26:9.9: In the same way, when a mendicant’s mind is rightly freed like this, even if compelling sights come into the range of vision they don’t occupy their mind.
an9.26:9.10: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, motionless, observing disappearance.
an9.26:10.5: and phenomena come into the range of the mind they don’t occupy the mind.
an9.26:10.6: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, motionless, observing disappearance.”
